For each neighborhood point D, we apply an adversarial attack to generate an adversarial point A with minimal perturbation that results in a different label than D. A second adversarial attack is then performed on A to generate a point A' that has the same label as D (and thus different than A). The points A and A' form an adversarial pair that brackets the local decision boundary for x_test. We then train a linear model on these adversarial pairs to approximate the local decision boundary. Experimental results on six UCI benchmark datasets across three deep neural network architectures demonstrate that our approach achieves higher stability and fidelity than the state-of-the-art.

item.title: CTR Prediction on Alibaba's Taobao Advertising Dataset Using Traditional and Deep Learning Models
item.content:encoded:
Click-through rate prediction, Transformer, user behavior modeling, deep learning, Taobao dataset

Summary: This study focuses on improving click-through rate (CTR) prediction essential for advertising systems by leveraging a large-scale Taobao dataset from Alibaba. Initially, traditional supervised models like logistic regression and Light-GBM were used, trained on static features including user demographics, ad characteristics, and contextual metadata, serving as interpretable and fast benchmarks but limited in capturing complex user behaviors. To better capture user intent, the researchers incorporated extensive behavioral data from hundreds of millions of interactions spanning 22 days. By encoding user action sequences, they created dynamic representations of user interests over time. Deep learning models, particularly multilayer perceptrons (MLPs), fused behavioral embeddings with static features and significantly improved performance. To further model temporal dynamics, a Transformer-based architecture employing self-attention mechanisms was proposed, effectively understanding contextual dependencies in user behaviors, including timing and frequency of interactions. This Transformer model improved the AUC metric by 2.81% compared to the logistic regression baseline, especially enhancing predictions for users with diverse or evolving interests. Beyond modeling, the study also suggested an A/B testing framework for practical evaluation. Finally, it discussed broader implications, advocating that personalized ad targeting techniques could be applied to public health for precise delivery of health information and behavioral guidance, thus extending the impact of CTR prediction research beyond e-commerce.
arXiv:2511.21963v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Click-through rates prediction is critical in modern advertising systems, where ranking relevance and user engagement directly impact platform efficiency and business value. In this project, we explore how to model CTR more effectively using a large-scale Taobao dataset released by Alibaba. We start with supervised learning models, including logistic regression and Light-GBM, that are trained on static features such as user demographics, ad attributes, and contextual metadata. These models provide fast, interpretable benchmarks, but have limited capabilities to capture patterns of behavior that drive clicks. To better model user intent, we combined behavioral data from hundreds of millions of interactions over a 22-day period. By extracting and encoding user action sequences, we construct representations of user interests over time. We use deep learning models to fuse behavioral embeddings with static features. Among them, multilayer perceptrons (MLPs) have achieved significant performance improvements. To capture temporal dynamics, we designed a Transformer-based architecture that uses a self-attention mechanism to learn contextual dependencies across behavioral sequences, modeling not only what the user interacts with, but also the timing and frequency of interactions. Transformer improves AUC by 2.81 % over the baseline (LR model), with the largest gains observed for users whose interests are diverse or change over time. In addition to modeling, we propose an A/B testing strategy for real-world evaluation. We also think about the broader implications: personalized ad targeting technology can be applied to public health scenarios to achieve precise delivery of health information or behavior guidance. Our research provides a roadmap for advancing click-through rate predictions and extending their value beyond e-commerce.

item.title: MOTIF-RF: Multi-template On-chip Transformer Synthesis Incorporating Frequency-domain Self-transfer Learning for RFIC Design Automation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: multi-template machine learning, inverse design, transformers, frequency-domain self-transfer learning, evolutionary strategy

Summary:

This paper systematically investigates the development of multi-template machine learning (ML) surrogate models tailored for the inverse design of transformers (XFMRs) used in radio-frequency integrated circuits (RFICs). Initially, it benchmarks four prevalent ML architectures—MLP, CNN, UNet, and GT—using consistent datasets across various transformer topologies to establish baseline performance. To surpass these baselines, the authors introduce a novel frequency-domain self-transfer learning technique that leverages correlations between adjacent frequency bands, resulting in significant prediction accuracy improvements of around 30% to 50% in S-parameters. Utilizing these enhanced ML models, the study proceeds to develop an inverse design framework centered on the covariance matrix adaptation evolutionary strategy (CMA-ES) algorithm. This framework is rigorously validated through multiple impedance-matching tasks, consistently demonstrating rapid convergence and reliable performance. Collectively, these advancements contribute toward the overarching goal of AI-powered automation for transforming specifications to physical layouts (specs-to-GDS) in RFIC design. The findings empower RFIC designers by integrating sophisticated AI tools into the design workflow, thereby accelerating design cycles and improving model reliability for practical applications in RFIC transformer design.
arXiv:2511.21970v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper presents a systematic study on developing multi-template machine learning (ML) surrogate models and applying them to the inverse design of transformers (XFMRs) in radio-frequency integrated circuits (RFICs). Our study starts with benchmarking four widely used ML architectures, including MLP-, CNN-, UNet-, and GT-based models, using the same datasets across different XFMR topologies. To improve modeling accuracy beyond these baselines, we then propose a new frequency-domain self-transfer learning technique that exploits correlations between adjacent frequency bands, leading to around 30%-50% accuracy improvement in the S-parameters prediction. Building on these models, we further develop an inverse design framework based on the covariance matrix adaptation evolutionary strategy (CMA-ES) algorithm. This framework is validated using multiple impedance-matching tasks, all demonstrating fast convergence and trustworthy performance. These results advance the goal of AI-assisted specs-to-GDS automation for RFICs and provide RFIC designers with actionable tools for integrating AI into their workflows.

item.title: A Safety and Security Framework for Real-World Agentic Systems
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: agentic AI, safety and security, risk taxonomy, AI-driven red teaming, enterprise deployment

Summary: This paper presents a dynamic, actionable framework designed to enhance the safety and security of agentic AI systems deployed in enterprise environments. It argues that safety and security emerge not just from individual models but from the complex interactions between models, orchestrators, tools, and data within their operating context. The authors introduce a novel approach to identifying new agentic risks through a user safety perspective, highlighting how safety and security concerns, traditionally distinct in isolated models, become interconnected in agentic systems. A unified operational agentic risk taxonomy is proposed, addressing classic safety and security issues alongside unique risks such as tool misuse, cascading action chains, and unintended control amplification. Central to the framework is a contextual agentic risk management approach leveraging auxiliary AI models and agents under human supervision to facilitate risk discovery, evaluation, and mitigation. The study emphasizes AI-driven, sandboxed red teaming as a key technique for uncovering hidden risks. Effectiveness is demonstrated through a detailed case study of NVIDIA’s AI-Q Research Assistant, illustrating comprehensive end-to-end safety and security assessments in complex agentic workflows. Finally, the authors release a dataset with over 10,000 simulated attack and defense scenarios, aiming to support further research in agentic AI safety.
arXiv:2511.21990v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper introduces a dynamic and actionable framework for securing agentic AI systems in enterprise deployment. We contend that safety and security are not merely fixed attributes of individual models but also emergent properties arising from the dynamic interactions among models, orchestrators, tools, and data within their operating environments. We propose a new way of identification of novel agentic risks through the lens of user safety. Although, for traditional LLMs and agentic models in isolation, safety and security has a clear separation, through the lens of safety in agentic systems, they appear to be connected. Building on this foundation, we define an operational agentic risk taxonomy that unifies traditional safety and security concerns with novel, uniquely agentic risks, including tool misuse, cascading action chains, and unintended control amplification among others. At the core of our approach is a dynamic agentic safety and security framework that operationalizes contextual agentic risk management by using auxiliary AI models and agents, with human oversight, to assist in contextual risk discovery, evaluation, and mitigation. We further address one of the most challenging aspects of safety and security of agentic systems: risk discovery through sandboxed, AI-driven red teaming. We demonstrate the framework effectiveness through a detailed case study of NVIDIA flagship agentic research assistant, AI-Q Research Assistant, showcasing practical, end-to-end safety and security evaluations in complex, enterprise-grade agentic workflows. This risk discovery phase finds novel agentic risks that are then contextually mitigated. We also release the dataset from our case study, containing traces of over 10,000 realistic attack and defense executions of the agentic workflow to help advance research in agentic safety.

item.title: Distance-based Learning of Hypertrees
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: hypergraphs, shortest-path queries, online algorithm, orderly hypertrees, evolutionary tree reconstruction

Summary:

1. This paper addresses the problem of learning hypergraphs using shortest-path queries (SP-queries), focusing on a novel and well-defined class of hypertrees named orderly hypertrees. 2. It introduces the first provably optimal online algorithm tailored for this class, which can also be converted to an optimal offline learning algorithm. 3. Orderly hypertrees are analyzed within the Fagin hierarchy, a framework in database theory that categorizes acyclic hypergraphs, and this class strictly includes the largest previously known class of acyclic hypergraphs that can be learned with subquadratic SP-query complexity. 4. Recognizing practical limitations in distance measurements, especially in applications like evolutionary tree reconstruction where distance accuracy decreases with increasing distance, the authors consider a bounded distance query model. 5. Within this bounded distance query framework, the paper establishes asymptotically tight complexity bounds for the problem of learning general hypertrees, thus expanding theoretical understanding and practical applicability in scenarios where query accuracy is limited.
arXiv:2511.22014v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We study the problem of learning hypergraphs with shortest-path queries (SP-queries), and present the first provably optimal online algorithm for a broad and natural class of hypertrees that we call orderly hypertrees. Our online algorithm can be transformed into a provably optimal offline algorithm. Orderly hypertrees can be positioned within the Fagin hierarchy of acyclic hypergraph (well-studied in database theory), and strictly encompass the broadest class in this hierarchy that is learnable with subquadratic SP-query complexity. Recognizing that in some contexts, such as evolutionary tree reconstruction, distance measurements can degrade with increased distance, we also consider a learning model that uses bounded distance queries. In this model, we demonstrate asymptotically tight complexity bounds for learning general hypertrees.

item.title: Equilibrium Propagation Without Limits
item.content:encoded:
Equilibrium Propagation, Helmholtz free energy, Contrastive Hebbian Learning, Gibbs-Boltzmann distribution, finite nudging

Summary:

This paper presents a significant advancement in Equilibrium Propagation (EP) by removing the traditional requirement for infinitesimal perturbations in the learning process. Instead, the authors introduce a finite-nudge framework that grounds local credit assignment more robustly. They achieve this by modeling network states probabilistically as Gibbs-Boltzmann distributions instead of deterministic points, enabling a more general and exact treatment. A key theoretical result demonstrated is that the gradient of the difference in Helmholtz free energy between the nudged phase and the free phase corresponds exactly to the difference in expected local energy derivatives. This insight provides a rigorous justification for the Contrastive Hebbian Learning update rule as an exact gradient estimator, even with large nudges, without relying on infinitesimal approximations or assumptions of convexity. Moreover, the study extends EP by deriving a generalized algorithm based on the path integral of loss-energy covariances, which supports learning with strong error signals—something that previous infinitesimal approximation methods could not handle effectively. Overall, this work broadens the applicability and theoretical foundation of EP for training neural networks, potentially improving learning efficiency and flexibility in practical scenarios.
arXiv:2511.22024v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We liberate Equilibrium Propagation (EP) from the limit of infinitesimal perturbations by establishing a finite-nudge foundation for local credit assignment. By modeling network states as Gibbs-Boltzmann distributions rather than deterministic points, we prove that the gradient of the difference in Helmholtz free energy between a nudged and free phase is exactly the difference in expected local energy derivatives. This validates the classic Contrastive Hebbian Learning update as an exact gradient estimator for arbitrary finite nudging, requiring neither infinitesimal approximations nor convexity. Furthermore, we derive a generalized EP algorithm based on the path integral of loss-energy covariances, enabling learning with strong error signals that standard infinitesimal approximations cannot support.

item.title: Calibration-Free EEG-based Driver Drowsiness Detection with Online Test-Time Adaptation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: EEG, drowsiness detection, test-time adaptation, batch normalization, prototype learning

Summary:

1. Drowsy driving significantly contributes to traffic accidents, and EEG-based detection systems are being explored to address this issue.
2. EEG signals show high inter-subject variability, causing domain shift problems and hindering generalization of detection models to new subjects.
3. The authors propose a novel driver drowsiness detection framework that leverages online test-time adaptation (TTA) by updating learnable parameters in batch normalization layers while preserving pretrained statistics.
4. A memory bank dynamically manages streaming EEG segments, selecting reliable samples based on negative energy scores and persistence time to improve adaptation.
5. Prototype learning is introduced to maintain robust predictions despite ongoing distribution shifts during operation.
6. The method was validated on a sustained-attention driving dataset in a simulated environment, where delayed reaction times during lane-keeping tasks served as drowsiness indicators.
7. Experimental results demonstrate the method outperforms all baselines, with an average F1-score of 81.73%, improving by 11.73% over the best existing TTA baseline.
8. This approach significantly advances the adaptability of EEG-based drowsiness detection systems in real-world, non-i.i.d. (non-independent and identically distributed) scenarios.
arXiv:2511.22030v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Drowsy driving is a growing cause of traffic accidents, prompting recent exploration of electroencephalography (EEG)-based drowsiness detection systems. However, the inherent variability of EEG signals due to psychological and physical factors necessitates a cumbersome calibration process. In particular, the inter-subject variability of EEG signals leads to a domain shift problem, which makes it challenging to generalize drowsiness detection models to unseen target subjects. To address these issues, we propose a novel driver drowsiness detection framework that leverages online test-time adaptation (TTA) methods to dynamically adjust to target subject distributions. Our proposed method updates the learnable parameters in batch normalization (BN) layers, while preserving pretrained normalization statistics, resulting in a modified configuration that ensures effective adaptation during test time. We incorporate a memory bank that dynamically manages streaming EEG segments, selecting samples based on their reliability determined by negative energy scores and persistence time. In addition, we introduce prototype learning to ensure robust predictions against distribution shifts over time. We validated our method on the sustained-attention driving dataset collected in a simulated environment, where drowsiness was estimated from delayed reaction times during monotonous lane-keeping tasks. Our experiments show that our method outperforms all baselines, achieving an average F1-score of 81.73\%, an improvement of 11.73\% over the best TTA baseline. This demonstrates that our proposed method significantly enhances the adaptability of EEG-based drowsiness detection systems in non-i.i.d. scenarios.

item.title: Predicting Public Health Impacts of Electricity Usage
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: electric power sector, air pollutant emissions, health-informed demand-side management, AI model, public health impacts

Summary:

1. The electric power sector is a major source of air pollutant emissions that adversely affect public health across communities despite existing regulatory efforts.
2. Fossil fuels continue to play a significant role in electricity generation, creating an urgent need for advanced demand-side strategies focused on reducing health impacts.
3. The study introduces HealthPredictor, a novel domain-specific AI model designed to link electricity consumption directly to public health outcomes through an integrated pipeline.
4. HealthPredictor comprises three components: a fuel mix predictor estimating generation source contributions, an air quality converter modeling pollutant emissions and dispersion, and a health impact assessor converting pollutant changes into monetized health damages.
5. Validation across multiple U.S. regions shows the AI-driven health optimization framework significantly outperforms baseline models that rely solely on fuel mix data in predicting public health effects.
6. A case study involving electric vehicle charging schedules demonstrates the model’s capability to guide energy management decisions that reduce negative health impacts.
7. The research highlights the potential for AI tools to advance health-informed energy management, contributing to improved public health and societal well-being.
8. The authors have made their datasets and code publicly available to support further research and application.
arXiv:2511.22031v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The electric power sector is a leading source of air pollutant emissions, impacting the public health of nearly every community. Although regulatory measures have reduced air pollutants, fossil fuels remain a significant component of the energy supply, highlighting the need for more advanced demand-side approaches to reduce the public health impacts. To enable health-informed demand-side management, we introduce HealthPredictor, a domain-specific AI model that provides an end-to-end pipeline linking electricity use to public health outcomes. The model comprises three components: a fuel mix predictor that estimates the contribution of different generation sources, an air quality converter that models pollutant emissions and atmospheric dispersion, and a health impact assessor that translates resulting pollutant changes into monetized health damages. Across multiple regions in the United States, our health-driven optimization framework yields substantially lower prediction errors in terms of public health impacts than fuel mix-driven baselines. A case study on electric vehicle charging schedules illustrates the public health gains enabled by our method and the actionable guidance it can offer for health-informed energy management. Overall, this work shows how AI models can be explicitly designed to enable health-informed energy management for advancing public health and broader societal well-being. Our datasets and code are released at: https://github.com/Ren-Research/Health-Impact-Predictor.

item.title: Convergence Dynamics of Over-Parameterized Score Matching for a Single Gaussian
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: score matching, gradient descent, over-parameterized models, Gaussian distribution, convergence guarantees

Summary: This paper investigates the optimization dynamics of score matching when training over-parameterized models to learn a single Gaussian distribution. First, it considers a student model with \( n \) parameters trained using population score matching on Gaussian data. Second, it establishes that in the large noise regime, gradient descent achieves global convergence to the ground truth parameters. Third, in the low noise regime, a stationary point exists, making global convergence difficult to prove generally. However, under the condition of exponentially small parameter initialization, gradient descent is shown to converge to the ground truth. Fourth, the study demonstrates that without such small initialization, parameters may fail to converge. Fifth, when parameters are randomly initialized from a Gaussian distribution far from the ground truth, only one parameter tends to converge while others diverge, yet the loss function still converges to zero at a rate of \( 1/\tau \), with \(\tau\) iterations. The paper also provides a nearly matching lower bound for this convergence rate. Importantly, this is the first work proving global convergence guarantees for Gaussian mixtures with at least three components under the score matching framework, advancing the theoretical understanding of score matching in generative modeling.
arXiv:2511.22069v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Score matching has become a central training objective in modern generative modeling, particularly in diffusion models, where it is used to learn high-dimensional data distributions through the estimation of score functions. Despite its empirical success, the theoretical understanding of the optimization behavior of score matching, particularly in over-parameterized regimes, remains limited. In this work, we study gradient descent for training over-parameterized models to learn a single Gaussian distribution. Specifically, we use a student model with $n$ learnable parameters and train it on data generated from a single ground-truth Gaussian using the population score matching objective. We analyze the optimization dynamics under multiple regimes. When the noise scale is sufficiently large, we prove a global convergence result for gradient descent. In the low-noise regime, we identify the existence of a stationary point, highlighting the difficulty of proving global convergence in this case. Nevertheless, we show convergence under certain initialization conditions: when the parameters are initialized to be exponentially small, gradient descent ensures convergence of all parameters to the ground truth. We further prove that without the exponentially small initialization, the parameters may not converge to the ground truth. Finally, we consider the case where parameters are randomly initialized from a Gaussian distribution far from the ground truth. We prove that, with high probability, only one parameter converges while the others diverge, yet the loss still converges to zero with a $1/\tau$ rate, where $\tau$ is the number of iterations. We also establish a nearly matching lower bound on the convergence rate in this regime. This is the first work to establish global convergence guarantees for Gaussian mixtures with at least three components under the score matching framework.

item.title: A Multi-View Multi-Timescale Hypergraph-Empowered Spatiotemporal Framework for EV Charging Forecasting
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: EV charging demand, hypergraphs, spatiotemporal forecasting, multi-view modeling, cross-attention

Summary: Accurate forecasting of electric vehicle (EV) charging demand is critical for maintaining grid stability and enabling EVs to actively participate in the electricity market. Current forecasting methods, particularly those using graph neural networks, typically focus only on pairwise relationships between charging stations, which limits their ability to capture the complex, group-wise interactions present in urban charging networks. To overcome this limitation, the authors propose HyperCast, a novel forecasting framework based on hypergraphs that can model higher-order spatiotemporal dependencies in EV charging patterns. HyperCast incorporates multi-view hypergraphs that represent both static geographical proximity and dynamic demand-based functional similarities among stations. It also integrates multi-timescale input data, allowing it to distinguish recent trends from weekly periodic patterns. The framework is equipped with specialized hyper-spatiotemporal blocks and custom cross-attention mechanisms to effectively combine information from multiple views and timescales. Extensive experiments on four public datasets demonstrate that HyperCast significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods, confirming the benefit of explicitly modeling collective charging behaviors for improved forecasting accuracy. This approach advances the capabilities of EV demand prediction by harnessing complex group interactions and multi-dimensional dependencies.
arXiv:2511.22072v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Accurate electric vehicle (EV) charging demand forecasting is essential for stable grid operation and proactive EV participation in electricity market. Existing forecasting methods, particularly those based on graph neural networks, are often limited to modeling pairwise relationships between stations, failing to capture the complex, group-wise dynamics inherent in urban charging networks. To address this gap, we develop a novel forecasting framework namely HyperCast, leveraging the expressive power of hypergraphs to model the higher-order spatiotemporal dependencies hidden in EV charging patterns. HyperCast integrates multi-view hypergraphs, which capture both static geographical proximity and dynamic demand-based functional similarities, along with multi-timescale inputs to differentiate between recent trends and weekly periodicities. The framework employs specialized hyper-spatiotemporal blocks and tailored cross-attention mechanisms to effectively fuse information from these diverse sources: views and timescales. Extensive experiments on four public datasets demonstrate that HyperCast significantly outperforms a wide array of state-of-the-art baselines, demonstrating the effectiveness of explicitly modeling collective charging behaviors for more accurate forecasting.

item.title: ARES: Anomaly Recognition Model For Edge Streams
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: temporal graphs, anomaly detection, edge streams, graph neural networks, half-space trees

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of real-time anomaly detection in temporal graphs, which model streaming information through dynamic edge changes. Identifying unusual temporal connections (edge anomalies) is critical for preventing risks in various real-world applications, but is complicated by factors such as concept drift, high data volumes, and the need for immediate responses. The authors propose ARES, an unsupervised framework that detects anomalies in edge streams by combining Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) with Half-Space Trees (HST). GNNs are used to extract features by embedding node and edge properties into a latent space, effectively capturing different anomalous patterns like spikes and bursts. HST then partitions this latent space to efficiently isolate anomalies. ARES operates without requiring labeled data, making it broadly applicable. Additionally, a supervised thresholding method based on statistical dispersion of anomaly scores is incorporated to optimize threshold setting using minimal labeled examples, enhancing adaptability across domains. The framework’s performance is demonstrated via extensive experiments on multiple real-world cyber-attack scenarios, showing competitive detection accuracy, as well as favorable space and time complexity when compared to existing methods.
arXiv:2511.22078v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Many real-world scenarios involving streaming information can be represented as temporal graphs, where data flows through dynamic changes in edges over time. Anomaly detection in this context has the objective of identifying unusual temporal connections within the graph structure. Detecting edge anomalies in real time is crucial for mitigating potential risks. Unlike traditional anomaly detection, this task is particularly challenging due to concept drifts, large data volumes, and the need for real-time response. To face these challenges, we introduce ARES, an unsupervised anomaly detection framework for edge streams. ARES combines Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) for feature extraction with Half-Space Trees (HST) for anomaly scoring. GNNs capture both spike and burst anomalous behaviors within streams by embedding node and edge properties in a latent space, while HST partitions this space to isolate anomalies efficiently. ARES operates in an unsupervised way without the need for prior data labeling. To further validate its detection capabilities, we additionally incorporate a simple yet effective supervised thresholding mechanism. This approach leverages statistical dispersion among anomaly scores to determine the optimal threshold using a minimal set of labeled data, ensuring adaptability across different domains. We validate ARES through extensive evaluations across several real-world cyber-attack scenarios, comparing its performance against existing methods while analyzing its space and time complexity.

item.title: A Fast and Flat Federated Learning Method via Weighted Momentum and Sharpness-Aware Minimization
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: federated learning, momentum, sharpness-aware minimization, non-IID, convergence

Summary: The paper addresses critical challenges in federated learning (FL), focusing on achieving fast convergence under tight communication constraints while ensuring model generalization across non-IID client data distributions. It identifies two key failure modes when combining momentum and sharpness-aware minimization (SAM) in FL: local-global curvature misalignment, where local SAM perturbations do not align with the global loss geometry, and momentum-echo oscillation, a late-stage instability caused by accumulated momentum. To mitigate these issues, the authors propose FedWMSAM, a novel method that introduces a momentum-guided global perturbation based on server-aggregated momentum to align clients’ SAM directions with the global descent geometry, enabling an efficient single-backprop SAM approximation. Additionally, they design a cosine-similarity adaptive rule to couple momentum and SAM, implementing an early-momentum, late-SAM two-phase training schedule that stabilizes training. Theoretical contributions include a non-IID convergence bound explicitly accounting for perturbation-induced variance and its dependence on system variables such as the number of clients, rounds, and local steps. Extensive experiments across multiple datasets and models demonstrate the method’s effectiveness, adaptability, robustness, and superiority over existing approaches in overcoming FL optimization challenges. The implementation code is publicly available.
arXiv:2511.22080v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In federated learning (FL), models must \emph{converge quickly} under tight communication budgets while \emph{generalizing} across non-IID client distributions. These twin requirements have naturally led to two widely used techniques: client/server \emph{momentum} to accelerate progress, and \emph{sharpness-aware minimization} (SAM) to prefer flat solutions. However, simply combining momentum and SAM leaves two structural issues unresolved in non-IID FL. We identify and formalize two failure modes: \emph{local-global curvature misalignment} (local SAM directions need not reflect the global loss geometry) and \emph{momentum-echo oscillation} (late-stage instability caused by accumulated momentum). To our knowledge, these failure modes have not been jointly articulated and addressed in the FL literature. We propose \textbf{FedWMSAM} to address both failure modes. First, we construct a momentum-guided global perturbation from server-aggregated momentum to align clients' SAM directions with the global descent geometry, enabling a \emph{single-backprop} SAM approximation that preserves efficiency. Second, we couple momentum and SAM via a cosine-similarity adaptive rule, yielding an early-momentum, late-SAM two-phase training schedule. We provide a non-IID convergence bound that \emph{explicitly models the perturbation-induced variance} $\sigma_\rho^2=\sigma^2+(L\rho)^2$ and its dependence on $(S, K, R, N)$ on the theory side. We conduct extensive experiments on multiple datasets and model architectures, and the results validate the effectiveness, adaptability, and robustness of our method, demonstrating its superiority in addressing the optimization challenges of Federated Learning. Our code is available at https://github.com/Huang-Yongzhi/NeurlPS_FedWMSAM.

item.title: Quantum Bayesian Optimization for Quality Improvement in Fuselage Assembly
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Quantum Bayesian Optimization, smart manufacturing, aerospace fuselage assembly, sample efficiency, shape control

Summary:

This paper addresses the challenge of improving sample efficiency in aerospace fuselage assembly through precise shape adjustment to minimize dimensional gaps between assembled sections. Traditional Monte Carlo methods require many samples to estimate mean responses accurately, causing inefficiency in manufacturing contexts. The authors propose a Quantum Bayesian Optimization (QBO) framework that leverages quantum algorithms capable of achieving similar estimation accuracy with fewer samples. QBO integrates a quantum oracle, which relies on finite element analysis (FEA) or surrogate models, to obtain more accurate environmental response estimations with fewer queries. The optimization uses an Upper Confidence Bound (UCB) acquisition function to strategically select input parameters that maximize the objective. The method is theoretically proven to reduce sample usage while maintaining optimization performance comparable to classical approaches. A case study involving force-controlled actuators applied to one fuselage section demonstrates QBO’s practical advantages in reducing dimensional error and uncertainty. Experimental results confirm that with the same number of queries, QBO outperforms classical methods in accuracy and reliability, indicating significant potential for improving manufacturing process efficiency in aerospace assembly through quantum-enhanced techniques.
arXiv:2511.22090v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent efforts in smart manufacturing have enhanced aerospace fuselage assembly processes, particularly by innovating shape adjustment techniques to minimize dimensional gaps between assembled sections. Existing approaches have shown promising results but face the issue of low sample efficiency from the manufacturing systems. It arises from the limitation of the classical Monte Carlo method when uncovering the mean response from a distribution. In contrast, recent work has shown that quantum algorithms can achieve the same level of estimation accuracy with significantly fewer samples than the classical Monte Carlo method from distributions. Therefore, we can adopt the estimation of the quantum algorithm to obtain the estimation from real physical systems (distributions). Motivated by this advantage, we propose a Quantum Bayesian Optimization (QBO) framework for precise shape control during assembly to improve the sample efficiency in manufacturing practice. Specifically, this approach utilizes a quantum oracle, based on finite element analysis (FEA)-based models or surrogate models, to acquire a more accurate estimation of the environment response with fewer queries for a certain input. QBO employs an Upper Confidence Bound (UCB) as the acquisition function to strategically select input values that are most likely to maximize the objective function. It has been theoretically proven to require much fewer samples while maintaining comparable optimization results. In the case study, force-controlled actuators are applied to one fuselage section to adjust its shape and reduce the gap to the adjoining section. Experimental results demonstrate that QBO achieves significantly lower dimensional error and uncertainty compared to classical methods, particularly using the same queries from the simulation.

item.title: Decomposed Trust: Exploring Privacy, Adversarial Robustness, Fairness, and Ethics of Low-Rank LLMs
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, low-rank factorization, trustworthiness, adversarial robustness, fairness

Summary: This paper investigates the trustworthiness implications of compressing large language models (LLMs) using low-rank factorization, a technique effective for reducing size, memory, and computation while maintaining accuracy. First, the study finds that low-rank compression tends to preserve or improve training data privacy but weakens protection of personally identifiable information (PII) during interactive conversations. Second, adversarial robustness of compressed LLMs is generally maintained and often enhanced, even when models undergo deep compression. Third, ethical reasoning abilities of LLMs degrade in zero-shot evaluation scenarios after compression, but this decline can be partially mitigated by employing few-shot prompting techniques. Fourth, the analysis reveals that fairness metrics deteriorate under low-rank compression. Additionally, the paper explores how factors such as model scale and fine-tuning impact trustworthiness, which are critical considerations in low-rank compression strategies. Finally, to guide the development of more trustworthy compressed models, a gradient-based attribution analysis is conducted to identify specific layers within LLMs that contribute most significantly to adversarial robustness, offering actionable insights for future compression methods balancing efficiency and trustworthiness.
arXiv:2511.22099v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have driven major advances across domains, yet their massive size hinders deployment in resource-constrained settings. Model compression addresses this challenge, with low-rank factorization emerging as a particularly effective method for reducing size, memory, and computation while maintaining accuracy. However, while these compressed models boast of benign performance and system-level advantages, their trustworthiness implications remain poorly understood. In this paper, we present the first comprehensive study of how low-rank factorization affects LLM trustworthiness across privacy, adversarial robustness, fairness, and ethical alignment. We evaluate multiple LLMs of different sizes and variants compressed with diverse low-rank algorithms, revealing key insights: (1) low-rank compression preserves or improves training data privacy but weakens PII protection during conversation; (2) adversarial robustness is generally preserved and often enhanced, even under deep compression; (3) ethical reasoning degrades in zero-shot settings but partially recovers with few-shot prompting; (4) fairness declines under compression. Beyond compression, we investigate how model scale and fine-tuning affect trustworthiness, as both are important in low-rank methods. To guide trustworthy compression strategies, we end our paper with a gradient-based attribution analysis to identify which layers in LLMs contribute most to adversarial robustness.

item.title: Adaptive Dueling Double Deep Q-networks in Uniswap V3 Replication and Extension with Mamba
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Uniswap V3, Deep Reinforcement Learning, Liquidity Provision, Mamba, DDQN

Summary:

This report reviews the replication and enhancement of the article "Adaptive Liquidity Provision in Uniswap V3 with Deep Reinforcement Learning." The replication section outlines the process of obtaining data from the Uniswap Subgraph, details the implementation steps, and offers commentary on the results achieved. Following the replication, a new model structure is proposed that integrates the Mamba framework with Double Deep Q-Networks (DDQN) and introduces a novel reward function designed to improve performance. Data cleaning is conducted again to ensure higher data quality and reliability. To evaluate the enhanced model, two new baselines are introduced for comprehensive comparison. Although the improved model has yet to be tested across all datasets, it demonstrates stronger theoretical foundations than the original model. Empirical testing on available datasets indicates that the new model outperforms the original in several key tests, suggesting potential for better adaptive liquidity provision strategies in Uniswap V3.
arXiv:2511.22101v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The report goes through the main steps of replicating and improving the article "Adaptive Liquidity Provision in Uniswap V3 with Deep Reinforcement Learning." The replication part includes how to obtain data from the Uniswap Subgraph, details of the implementation, and comments on the results. After the replication, I propose a new structure based on the original model, which combines Mamba with DDQN and a new reward function. In this new structure, I clean the data again and introduce two new baselines for comparison. As a result, although the model has not yet been applied to all datasets, it shows stronger theoretical support than the original model and performs better in some tests.

item.title: Representative Action Selection for Large Action Space: From Bandits to MDPs
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: reinforcement learning, action subset selection, Markov Decision Processes, meta-bandits, non-centered sub-Gaussian process

Summary:

1. The article addresses the challenge of selecting a small yet representative subset of actions from a large shared action space across multiple reinforcement learning (RL) environments. This problem is particularly relevant in domains like inventory management and recommendation systems where evaluating every action is infeasible.

2. The goal is to identify a fixed subset of actions that contains a near-optimal action for each environment in a family, thus enabling efficient learning without the computational burden of exploring the entire action space.

3. This work generalizes previous results from the meta-bandit framework to the broader context of Markov Decision Processes (MDPs), thereby extending applicability to more complex decision-making problems.

4. The authors prove that their existing algorithm performs comparably to using the full action space, providing strong theoretical guarantees even under relaxed assumptions characterized by a non-centered sub-Gaussian process model. This model allows for greater heterogeneity among environments.

5. Overall, the proposed approach offers a computationally and sample-efficient method for large-scale combinatorial decision-making under uncertainty, making it valuable for real-world applications involving diverse and complex RL settings.
arXiv:2511.22104v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We study the problem of selecting a small, representative action subset from an extremely large action space shared across a family of reinforcement learning (RL) environments -- a fundamental challenge in applications like inventory management and recommendation systems, where direct learning over the entire space is intractable. Our goal is to identify a fixed subset of actions that, for every environment in the family, contains a near-optimal action, thereby enabling efficient learning without exhaustively evaluating all actions. This work extends our prior results for meta-bandits to the more general setting of Markov Decision Processes (MDPs). We prove that our existing algorithm achieves performance comparable to using the full action space. This theoretical guarantee is established under a relaxed, non-centered sub-Gaussian process model, which accommodates greater environmental heterogeneity. Consequently, our approach provides a computationally and sample-efficient solution for large-scale combinatorial decision-making under uncertainty.

item.title: Energy Efficient Sleep Mode Optimization in 5G mmWave Networks via Multi Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning
item.content:encoded:
Dynamic sleep mode optimization (SMO), millimeter-wave networks, multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MARL), energy efficiency (EE), quality-of-service (QoS)

Summary: This paper addresses dynamic sleep mode optimization (SMO) in millimeter-wave (mmWave) networks to enhance energy efficiency (EE) while adhering to strict quality-of-service (QoS) constraints. Unlike traditional approaches that use static and aggregated base station (BS) traffic models, this work captures the inherent non-stationary traffic dynamics by introducing a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MARL) framework based on Double Deep Q-Network (DDQN), named MARL-DDQN. The framework operates in a realistic 3D urban environment incorporating time-varying, community-based user equipment (UE) mobility. MARL-DDQN supports scalable and distributed decision-making across multiple agents, reducing signaling overhead compared to single-agent RL methods. The study integrates an accurate BS power consumption model and beamforming techniques to effectively quantify EE. QoS is measured via throughput, ensuring fairness and mitigating inter-cell interference. Simulation results demonstrate that MARL-DDQN significantly outperforms existing methods such as All On, iterative QoS-aware load-based (IT-QoS-LB), MARL-DDPG, and MARL-PPO. The proposed approach achieves up to 0.60 Mbit/Joule in EE, delivers an 8.5 Mbps 10th-percentile throughput, and satisfies QoS constraints 95% of the time in dynamic scenarios, proving its effectiveness and practicality for real-world mmWave network deployments.
arXiv:2511.22105v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Dynamic sleep mode optimization (SMO) in millimeter-wave (mmWave) networks is essential for maximizing energy efficiency (EE) under stringent quality-of-service (QoS) constraints. However, existing optimization and reinforcement learning (RL) approaches rely on aggregated, static base station (BS) traffic models that fail to capture non-stationary traffic dynamics and suffer from large state-action spaces, limiting real-world deployment. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning (MARL) framework using a Double Deep Q-Network (DDQN), referred to as MARL-DDQN, for adaptive SMO in a 3D urban environment with a time-varying and community-based user equipment (UE) mobility model. Unlike conventional single-agent RL, MARL-DDQN enables scalable, distributed decision-making with minimal signaling overhead. A realistic BS power consumption model and beamforming are integrated to accurately quantify EE, while QoS is defined in terms of throughput. The method adapts SMO policies to maximize EE while mitigating inter-cell interference and ensuring throughput fairness. Simulations show that MARL-DDQN outperforms state-of-the-art strategies, including All On, iterative QoS-aware load-based (IT-QoS-LB), MARL-DDPG, and MARL-PPO, achieving up to 0.60 Mbit/Joule EE, 8.5 Mbps 10th-percentile throughput, and meeting QoS constraints 95% of the time under dynamic scenarios.

item.title: An energy-efficient spiking neural network with continuous learning for self-adaptive brain-machine interface
item.content:encoded:
Continuous learning, Deep Spiking Neural Networks, Reinforcement Learning, implantable brain-machine interfaces, energy efficiency

Summary: The number of neurons recorded simultaneously in implantable brain-machine interfaces (iBMIs) is exponentially increasing, necessitating efficient data compression strategies. Integrating the neural decoder within the implant offers a solution, but decoder performance often suffers due to system non-stationarity. Continuous learning is therefore critical for maintaining reliable operation without frequent retraining, which also ensures user safety and comfort. Deep Spiking Neural Networks (DSNNs) are promising candidates for resource-efficient neural decoding compatible with the energy constraints of iBMIs. This work proposes continuous learning methods using Reinforcement Learning (RL) algorithms, specifically Banditron and AGREL, adapted for DSNNs. These algorithms are computationally lightweight and effectively address non-stationarity. Experiments were conducted in both open-loop and closed-loop formats. In open-loop tests, DSNN Banditron and DSNN AGREL maintained stable accuracy over extended durations. In closed-loop experiments with perturbations, DSNN Banditron’s performance in time-to-target matched that of DSNN AGREL but achieved significant reductions of 98% in memory access and 99% in multiply-and-accumulate operations during training. Compared to prior continuous learning SNN decoders, DSNN Banditron’s drastically lower computational demand makes it an excellent candidate for future wireless iBMI systems.
arXiv:2511.22108v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The number of simultaneously recorded neurons follows an exponentially increasing trend in implantable brain-machine interfaces (iBMIs). Integrating the neural decoder in the implant is an effective data compression method for future wireless iBMIs. However, the non-stationarity of the system makes the performance of the decoder unreliable. To avoid frequent retraining of the decoder and to ensure the safety and comfort of the iBMI user, continuous learning is essential for real-life applications. Since Deep Spiking Neural Networks (DSNNs) are being recognized as a promising approach for developing resource-efficient neural decoder, we propose continuous learning approaches with Reinforcement Learning (RL) algorithms adapted for DSNNs. Banditron and AGREL are chosen as the two candidate RL algorithms since they can be trained with limited computational resources, effectively addressing the non-stationary problem and fitting the energy constraints of implantable devices. To assess the effectiveness of the proposed methods, we conducted both open-loop and closed-loop experiments. The accuracy of open-loop experiments conducted with DSNN Banditron and DSNN AGREL remains stable over extended periods. Meanwhile, the time-to-target in the closed-loop experiment with perturbations, DSNN Banditron performed comparably to that of DSNN AGREL while achieving reductions of 98% in memory access usage and 99% in the requirements for multiply- and-accumulate (MAC) operations during training. Compared to previous continuous learning SNN decoders, DSNN Banditron requires 98% less computes making it a prime candidate for future wireless iBMI systems.

item.title: Toward Data-Driven Surrogates of the Solar Wind with Spherical Fourier Neural Operator
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: solar wind, surrogate modeling, Spherical Fourier Neural Operator, space weather forecasting, magnetohydrodynamic models

Summary:
1. The solar wind, a stream of charged particles from the Sun’s corona, significantly influences the heliosphere and space systems near Earth, where its variations can disrupt satellites, power grids, and communications.
2. Accurate modeling of solar wind variations like high-speed streams and coronal mass ejections is crucial for effective space weather forecasting.
3. Traditional 3D magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) models simulate these variations but are computationally intensive, limiting their use for analyzing impacts of boundary condition uncertainties.
4. This work introduces a surrogate modeling approach for steady-state solar wind using a Spherical Fourier Neural Operator (SFNO).
5. The SFNO surrogate is compared to the existing HUX numerical surrogate, showing comparable or improved performance on multiple evaluation metrics.
6. Although HUX exhibits greater physical smoothness, this highlights the need for better evaluation metrics rather than a limitation of SFNO.
7. SFNO is flexible, trainable, and supports efficient real-time forecasting, with the ability to improve as more data become available.
8. The source code and additional visual results are publicly accessible on GitHub, supporting transparency and reproducibility.
arXiv:2511.22112v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The solar wind, a continuous stream of charged particles from the Sun's corona, shapes the heliosphere and impacts space systems near Earth. Variations such as high-speed streams and coronal mass ejections can disrupt satellites, power grids, and communications, making accurate modeling essential for space weather forecasting. While 3D magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) models are used to simulate and investigate these variations in the solar wind, they tend to be computationally expensive, limiting their usefulness in investigating the impacts of boundary condition uncertainty. In this work, we develop a surrogate for steady state solar wind modeling, using a Spherical Fourier Neural Operator (SFNO). We compare our model to a previously developed numerical surrogate for this task called HUX, and we show that the SFNO achieves comparable or better performance across several metrics. Though HUX retains advantages in physical smoothness, this underscores the need for improved evaluation criteria rather than a flaw in SFNO. As a flexible and trainable approach, SFNO enables efficient real-time forecasting and can improve with more data. The source code and more visual results are available at https://github.com/rezmansouri/solarwind-sfno-velocity.

item.title: IVGAE: Handling Incomplete Heterogeneous Data with a Variational Graph Autoencoder
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: missing data imputation, heterogeneous data, variational graph autoencoder, dual-decoder architecture, Transformer embedding

Summary:

1. The paper addresses the challenge of imputing missing values in real-world tabular datasets, particularly when data involve heterogeneous numerical and categorical features. 2. Existing imputation methods often struggle to capture complex dependencies between samples and features, limiting their effectiveness on heterogeneous data. 3. The authors propose IVGAE, a Variational Graph Autoencoder framework that models data as a bipartite graph connecting samples and features, enabling graph representation learning to better capture structural relationships. 4. A novel dual-decoder architecture is introduced, consisting of one decoder that reconstructs feature embeddings and another that models missingness patterns, thus incorporating structural priors that are aware of the missing data mechanisms. 5. To efficiently handle categorical variables, a Transformer-based heterogeneous embedding module replaces traditional one-hot encoding, reducing dimensionality and enhancing encoding quality. 6. The framework is extensively tested on 16 real-world datasets across different missing data scenarios—MCAR (Missing Completely At Random), MAR (Missing At Random), and MNAR (Missing Not At Random)—with missing rates up to 30%. 7. IVGAE consistently outperforms baseline methods in terms of RMSE for imputation quality and F1 score for downstream tasks, demonstrating robustness and effectiveness. 8. The authors provide open-source code and datasets at the given GitHub repository to facilitate reproducibility and further research.
arXiv:2511.22116v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Handling missing data remains a fundamental challenge in real-world tabular datasets, especially when data are heterogeneous with both numerical and categorical features. Existing imputation methods often fail to capture complex structural dependencies and handle heterogeneous data effectively. We present \textbf{IVGAE}, a Variational Graph Autoencoder framework for robust imputation of incomplete heterogeneous data. IVGAE constructs a bipartite graph to represent sample-feature relationships and applies graph representation learning to model structural dependencies. A key innovation is its \textit{dual-decoder architecture}, where one decoder reconstructs feature embeddings and the other models missingness patterns, providing structural priors aware of missing mechanisms. To better encode categorical variables, we introduce a Transformer-based heterogeneous embedding module that avoids high-dimensional one-hot encoding. Extensive experiments on 16 real-world datasets show that IVGAE achieves consistent improvements in RMSE and downstream F1 across MCAR, MAR, and MNAR missing scenarios under 30\% missing rates. Code and data are available at: https://github.com/echoid/IVGAE.

item.title: A Variational Manifold Embedding Framework for Nonlinear Dimensionality Reduction
item.content:encoded:
Dimensionality reduction, PCA, nonlinear embeddings, variational framework, manifold learning

Summary:

1. This paper addresses the limitations of traditional dimensionality reduction methods such as principal component analysis (PCA), notably their inability to capture nonlinear structures within data manifolds. 2. It introduces a novel variational framework that conceptualizes dimensionality reduction as an optimal manifold embedding problem, thereby enabling more flexible, nonlinear embeddings than PCA. 3. The framework's variational nature provides interpretability benefits—in particular, each solution derived from this approach satisfies a specific set of partial differential equations, linking the embedding process to the underlying mathematical structure. 4. The authors analyze how the solutions reflect symmetries inherent to the embedding objective, further deepening the understanding of the learned representations. 5. In addition to theoretical insights, the framework can be analytically characterized in various scenarios, and interestingly, it recovers PCA exactly as a special case, demonstrating its generality and connection to classical methods.
arXiv:2511.22128v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Dimensionality reduction algorithms like principal component analysis (PCA) are workhorses of machine learning and neuroscience, but each has well-known limitations. Variants of PCA are simple and interpretable, but not flexible enough to capture nonlinear data manifold structure. More flexible approaches have other problems: autoencoders are generally difficult to interpret, and graph-embedding-based methods can produce pathological distortions in manifold geometry. Motivated by these shortcomings, we propose a variational framework that casts dimensionality reduction algorithms as solutions to an optimal manifold embedding problem. By construction, this framework permits nonlinear embeddings, allowing its solutions to be more flexible than PCA. Moreover, the variational nature of the framework has useful consequences for interpretability: each solution satisfies a set of partial differential equations, and can be shown to reflect symmetries of the embedding objective. We discuss these features in detail and show that solutions can be analytically characterized in some cases. Interestingly, one special case exactly recovers PCA.

item.title: Benchmarking In-context Experiential Learning Through Repeated Product Recommendations
item.content:encoded:
Experiential Learning, Product Recommendation, User Personas, Large Language Models, Adaptive Agents

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of enabling agents to operate effectively in dynamic real-world environments where knowledge is incomplete and preferences shift over time. It highlights a critical gap in current evaluations, which tend to focus on tasks without ambiguity and fail to assess an agent’s capacity for adaptive, experiential learning. The authors introduce a new benchmark named BELA (Benchmark for Experiential Learning and Active exploration) tailored to test and promote in-context experiential learning within a product recommendation setting. BELA integrates three core components: a diverse set of real-world products from Amazon, multiple user personas encapsulating different and latent consumer preferences, and a large language model–based user simulator driven by these personas to generate interactive dialogue trajectories. Through this setup, agents must learn and refine their recommendations over multiple episodes by actively gathering information and adapting to evolving preferences expressed in natural language conversations. Experimental results reveal that state-of-the-art models currently underperform on this benchmark, showing limited improvement across interactions, which underscores the need for developing more agentic systems that are capable of effective in-context learning and adaptive reasoning through experience.
arXiv:2511.22130v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: To reliably navigate ever-shifting real-world environments, agents must grapple with incomplete knowledge and adapt their behavior through experience. However, current evaluations largely focus on tasks that leave no ambiguity, and do not measure agents' ability to adaptively learn and reason through the experiences they accrued. We exemplify the need for this in-context experiential learning in a product recommendation context, where agents must navigate shifting customer preferences and product landscapes through natural language dialogue. We curate a benchmark for experiential learning and active exploration (BELA) that combines (1) rich real-world products from Amazon, (2) a diverse collection of user personas to represent heterogeneous yet latent preferences, and (3) a LLM user simulator powered by the persona to create rich interactive trajectories. We observe that current frontier models struggle to meaningfully improve across episodes, underscoring the need for agentic systems with strong in-context learning capabilities.

item.title: Probabilistic Digital Twin for Misspecified Structural Dynamical Systems via Latent Force Modeling and Bayesian Neural Networks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: probabilistic digital twin, Gaussian Process Latent Force Models, Bayesian Neural Networks, uncertainty quantification, model-form errors

Summary: This article introduces a probabilistic digital twin framework designed for response prediction in dynamical systems where the governing physics models are misspecified. The method combines Gaussian Process Latent Force Models (GPLFM) with Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs) to provide an end-to-end approach that incorporates uncertainty throughout inference and prediction stages. During the diagnosis phase, model-form errors (MFEs) are modeled as latent input forces added to a nominal linear dynamical system and are jointly estimated alongside system states using GPLFM based on sensor data. Subsequently, a BNN is trained on posterior samples to learn a probabilistic nonlinear mapping from system states to MFEs, capturing diagnostic uncertainty effectively. In the prognosis phase, this learned mapping generates pseudo-measurements that feed into Kalman filtering for improved state prediction. This framework ensures systematic propagation of uncertainty from diagnosis to prediction, enhancing the reliability and trustworthiness of digital twins. The effectiveness and robustness of the framework are validated through four nonlinear system examples: a single degree of freedom (DOF) oscillator, a multi-DOF system, the Bouc-Wen hysteretic benchmark, and the Silverbox experimental dataset, demonstrating strong predictive accuracy and robustness to model misspecification.
arXiv:2511.22133v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This work presents a probabilistic digital twin framework for response prediction in dynamical systems governed by misspecified physics. The approach integrates Gaussian Process Latent Force Models (GPLFM) and Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs) to enable end-to-end uncertainty-aware inference and prediction. In the diagnosis phase, model-form errors (MFEs) are treated as latent input forces to a nominal linear dynamical system and jointly estimated with system states using GPLFM from sensor measurements. A BNN is then trained on posterior samples to learn a probabilistic nonlinear mapping from system states to MFEs, while capturing diagnostic uncertainty. For prognosis, this mapping is used to generate pseudo-measurements, enabling state prediction via Kalman filtering. The framework allows for systematic propagation of uncertainty from diagnosis to prediction, a key capability for trustworthy digital twins. The framework is demonstrated using four nonlinear examples: a single degree of freedom (DOF) oscillator, a multi-DOF system, and two established benchmarks -- the Bouc-Wen hysteretic system and the Silverbox experimental dataset -- highlighting its predictive accuracy and robustness to model misspecification.

item.title: TinyLLM: Evaluation and Optimization of Small Language Models for Agentic Tasks on Edge Devices
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: small language models, agentic tasks, edge devices, hybrid optimization, Direct Preference Optimization (DPO)

Summary: This paper investigates the effectiveness of small language models (SLMs) on agentic tasks such as function, tool, and API calling, with a focus on enabling autonomous agents to run on edge devices without cloud dependency. The authors evaluate these models using the Berkeley Function Calling Leaderboard (BFCL) framework, covering categories like simple, multiple, parallel, parallel-multiple, and relevance detection, assessing both live and non-live scenarios including multi-turn evaluations. They explore various parameter-driven optimization strategies including supervised fine-tuning (SFT), parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT), reinforcement learning (RL), Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) for preference alignment, and hybrid combinations of these methods. The study reports results for models such as TinyAgent, TinyLlama, Qwen, and xLAM. Additionally, a DPO training pipeline was constructed from AgentBank datasets (e.g., ALFRED), converting SFT data into chosen-rejected pairs via TinyLlama-generated rejected outputs and manual validation. Results show a significant performance gap between medium-sized models (1-3 billion parameters) and ultra-compact models (<1 billion parameters), with medium-sized models reaching up to 65.74% overall accuracy and 55.62% multi-turn accuracy using hybrid optimization. The findings emphasize that hybrid optimization strategies enable SLMs to deliver accurate, efficient, and stable agentic AI capable of running privately and with low latency on edge devices, advancing practical cloud-independent autonomous agents.
arXiv:2511.22138v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper investigates the effectiveness of small language models (SLMs) for agentic tasks (function/tool/API calling) with a focus on running agents on edge devices without reliance on cloud infrastructure. We evaluate SLMs using the Berkeley Function Calling Leaderboard (BFCL) framework and describe parameter-driven optimization strategies that include supervised fine-tuning (SFT), parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT), reinforcement learning (RL)-based optimization, preference alignment via Direct Preference Optimization (DPO), and hybrid methods. We report results for models including TinyAgent, TinyLlama, Qwen, and xLAM across BFCL categories (simple, multiple, parallel, parallel-multiple, and relevance detection), both in live and non-live settings, and in multi-turn evaluations. We additionally detail a DPO training pipeline constructed from AgentBank data (e.g., ALFRED), including our conversion of SFT data to chosen-rejected pairs using TinyLlama responses as rejected outputs and manual validation. Our results demonstrate clear accuracy differences across model scales where medium-sized models (1-3B parameters) significantly outperform ultra-compact models (<1B parameters), achieving up to 65.74% overall accuracy, and 55.62% multi-turn accuracy with hybrid optimization. This study highlights the importance of hybrid optimization strategies that enable small language models to deliver accurate, efficient, and stable agentic AI on edge devices, making privacy-preserving, low-latency autonomous agents practical beyond the cloud.

item.title: From Topology to Retrieval: Decoding Embedding Spaces with Unified Signatures
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: embeddings, topology, geometry, text models, retrievability

Summary:

1. This paper investigates how text embeddings are organized in space to improve model interpretability and understand factors influencing downstream task performance.
2. The authors conduct a comprehensive analysis of various topological and geometric measures across multiple text embedding models and datasets.
3. They find a high degree of redundancy among these individual metrics, which often fail to sufficiently distinguish between different embedding spaces.
4. To address these limitations, the paper introduces Unified Topological Signatures (UTS), a holistic framework designed to characterize embedding spaces by integrating multiple attributes.
5. The study demonstrates that UTS can effectively predict model-specific properties and reveal similarities driven by underlying model architecture.
6. Furthermore, UTS is shown to link the topological structure of embeddings with ranking effectiveness and to accurately predict document retrievability.
7. Overall, the findings emphasize the necessity of a multi-attribute, holistic approach to fully understand and leverage the geometric and topological properties of text embeddings in practical applications.
arXiv:2511.22150v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Studying how embeddings are organized in space not only enhances model interpretability but also uncovers factors that drive downstream task performance. In this paper, we present a comprehensive analysis of topological and geometric measures across a wide set of text embedding models and datasets. We find a high degree of redundancy among these measures and observe that individual metrics often fail to sufficiently differentiate embedding spaces. Building on these insights, we introduce Unified Topological Signatures (UTS), a holistic framework for characterizing embedding spaces. We show that UTS can predict model-specific properties and reveal similarities driven by model architecture. Further, we demonstrate the utility of our method by linking topological structure to ranking effectiveness and accurately predicting document retrievability. We find that a holistic, multi-attribute perspective is essential to understanding and leveraging the geometry of text embeddings.

item.title: Designing Instance-Level Sampling Schedules via REINFORCE with James-Stein Shrinkage
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: text-to-image samplers, sampling schedule, Dirichlet policy, James-Stein estimator, Stable Diffusion

Summary: This paper proposes a novel post-training approach for text-to-image samplers that focuses on rescheduling the sampling timeline rather than modifying model weights. Unlike traditional fixed, global schedules, the authors introduce instance-level schedules conditioned on prompts and noise, learned through a single-pass Dirichlet policy. To achieve accurate gradient estimates in the high-dimensional policy learning setting, they develop a new reward baseline based on a James-Stein estimator, which provably reduces estimation error compared to existing methods, enhancing performance. The rescheduled samplers demonstrate improved text-image alignment, better text rendering, and enhanced compositional control across popular models like Stable Diffusion and Flux. Importantly, a 5-step Flux-Dev sampler using this scheduling framework matches the generation quality of specialized, distilled samplers such as Flux-Schnell, showing efficiency gains without retraining or distillation. The work presents their adaptive scheduling as a model-agnostic, post-training tool that unlocks further generative capabilities in pretrained samplers, offering a practical and scalable alternative to weight fine-tuning or distillation for improving synthesis quality.
arXiv:2511.22177v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Most post-training methods for text-to-image samplers focus on model weights: either fine-tuning the backbone for alignment or distilling it for few-step efficiency. We take a different route: rescheduling the sampling timeline of a frozen sampler. Instead of a fixed, global schedule, we learn instance-level (prompt- and noise-conditioned) schedules through a single-pass Dirichlet policy. To ensure accurate gradient estimates in high-dimensional policy learning, we introduce a novel reward baseline based on a principled James-Stein estimator; it provably achieves lower estimation errors than commonly used variants and leads to superior performance. Our rescheduled samplers consistently improve text-image alignment including text rendering and compositional control across modern Stable Diffusion and Flux model families. Additionally, a 5-step Flux-Dev sampler with our schedules can attain generation quality comparable to deliberately distilled samplers like Flux-Schnell. We thus position our scheduling framework as an emerging model-agnostic post-training lever that unlocks additional generative potential in pretrained samplers.

item.title: PULSE-ICU: A Pretrained Unified Long-Sequence Encoder for Multi-task Prediction in Intensive Care Units
item.content:encoded:
ICU data, self-supervised learning, foundation model, Longformer, clinical prediction

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of modeling intensive care unit (ICU) data, which is inherently irregular, heterogeneous, and temporally fragmented, making clinical prediction difficult to generalize. The authors introduce PULSE-ICU, a self-supervised foundation model designed to learn event-level representations directly from large-scale electronic health record (EHR) sequences without needing data resampling or manual feature engineering. A unified embedding module captures multiple aspects of ICU data, including event identity, continuous values, measurement units, and temporal information. PULSE-ICU employs a Longformer-based encoder, which efficiently processes long time-series trajectories within ICU records. The model was fine-tuned across 18 diverse clinical prediction tasks such as mortality prediction, intervention forecasting, and phenotype identification, demonstrating robust and strong performance across all tasks. Additionally, external validation on datasets like eICU, HiRID, and P12 revealed that PULSE-ICU maintains high accuracy with minimal fine-tuning, indicating strong robustness to domain shifts and varying dataset constraints. These results highlight that foundation-style modeling can enhance data efficiency and adaptability in clinical settings and offers a scalable framework for ICU decision support tools adaptable to multiple clinical environments.
arXiv:2511.22199v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Intensive care unit (ICU) data are highly irregular, heterogeneous, and temporally fragmented, posing challenges for generalizable clinical prediction. We present PULSE-ICU, a self-supervised foundation model that learns event-level ICU representations from large-scale EHR sequences without resampling or manual feature engineering. A unified embedding module encodes event identity, continuous values, units, and temporal attributes, while a Longformer-based encoder enables efficient modeling of long trajectories. PULSE-ICU was fine-tuned across 18 prediction tasks, including mortality, intervention forecasting, and phenotype identification, achieving strong performance across task types. External validation on eICU, HiRID, and P12 showed substantial improvements with minimal fine-tuning, demonstrating robustness to domain shift and variable constraints. These findings suggest that foundation-style modeling can improve data efficiency and adaptability, providing a scalable framework for ICU decision support across diverse clinical environments.

item.title: BiCQL-ML: A Bi-Level Conservative Q-Learning Framework for Maximum Likelihood Inverse Reinforcement Learning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Offline Inverse Reinforcement Learning, BiCQL-ML, Conservative Q-Learning, Reward Recovery, Soft-Optimal Policy

Summary:

1. The paper addresses the problem of offline inverse reinforcement learning (IRL), which recovers a reward function explaining expert behavior without requiring any online environment interaction, relying solely on fixed demonstration data.

2. The authors propose BiCQL-ML, a novel policy-free offline IRL algorithm that simultaneously learns a reward function and a conservative Q-function within a bi-level optimization framework, avoiding the need to explicitly learn a policy.

3. BiCQL-ML iteratively alternates between (i) learning a conservative Q-function through Conservative Q-Learning (CQL) under the current reward estimate, and (ii) updating reward parameters by maximizing the expected Q-values of expert actions while limiting over-generalization to out-of-distribution actions.

4. The method is interpretable as performing maximum likelihood estimation under a soft value matching principle, and the authors provide theoretical guarantees demonstrating that BiCQL-ML converges to a reward function for which the expert policy is soft-optimal.
